review_title: Supportive, progressive, school with integrity that does its best to support faculty
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in San Diego, CA
pros: As adjunct faculty, I feel supported and valued. Everyone I've worked with has been caring, helpful, and professional. Constructive feedback is always kind and my success is celebrated. I never feel like there's a question that I can't ask or like I'm "bothering" my supervisor by asking. It keeps getting better all the time because of the dedication and efforts of the staff.
cons: It's a smaller school, so sometimes getting an answer or response takes time, but it's clear that everyone I've interacted cares about students and coworkers and loves the job they do.

job_title: Associate Professor in New York, NY
pros: Lots of students with diverse backgrounds makes for an interesting teaching environment.
cons: The school is run by incompetent beaurocrats. It's not just that they're bad at administrating, it's that they can't do well when they want to. It's disjointed and lacks any soul. Were this an accounting school that wouldn't really matter. But the school sells, and the students come for, passion.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in San Diego, CA
pros: Caring culture with students and colleagues
cons: Rapidly growing and slow to hire adequate numbers of faculty. They do ask for and hire consultants for important work and that is excellent.

review_title: They do not pay well, but the job is flexible
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Flexible, remote, work from home
cons: Low Pay, boring, they ask for a lot but pay is low for having a Doctorate degree.

job_title: Clinic Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Workers are hard working and try their best
cons: Don’t treat people nice and aren’t supportive

review_title: Excellent training for integrative health providers
job_title: Director of Outreach in New York, NY
pros: Leader in the profession with a wide variety of resources
cons: If you don't like NYC, you won't be happy at an NYC College

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: Taught for 5 years. Great community.
cons: Diversifying its identity to include trendy alternative health modes.

review_title: Poor pay and little care for employees
job_title: Instructor in San Diego, CA
pros: Some very nice people work here, many students are very dedicated and make job feel worth it
cons: Very low pay - seriously, it is wrong to start people with advanced degrees and experience at $25-35 per hour. Come on! Many people work there forever - and have little experience treating patients in their own practice. What makes a huge majority of the instructors/professors qualified to work there? No idea. They know what's in books but the medicine is much more than what's in books. The Chinese professors are all great, and know their stuff but few if any are actually listened to. There is a lot of complacency in this school and lots of people who have put in the time and that's what gets you somewhere, not actually what you know or what experience you have.

review_title: Good work environment, but unreasonable compensation for skill set required
job_title: Faculty in Chicago, IL
pros: Most administrators and faculty are bright, energetic people who are a pleasure to interact and work with. The students and my love of education are what keep me here, however.
cons: Compensation packages are ridiculous when compared with what professionals can make in private practice in the field. It would be impossible to make this a satisfying career if it was my only job. Even though I am considered "full-time," I maintain a part-time private practice and another business to continue to grow as a professional - both financially and intellectually.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Any incompetence you show is eclipsed by the rest of the employees and managers working there or running the college. There are some great people that work at PCOM but anyone with any brains or competency gets pushed out of the organization.
cons: Horrible pay, worse benefits, completely disorganized company structure, most of the decision makers have no idea how the school actually runs, top-down ignorant decision making, and absolutely no investment in employee training or success. Grossly incompetent employees get promoted to positions despite multiple objections from the people that work closely with them.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: I have worked for PCOM over 3 years. I have developed valuable professional relationships while working for the college. They offer benefits including 401k, medical, dental, and vision. The pay is competitive to market rates. The opportunity for growth exists. The culture is one of work life balance. They offer free acupuncture and massage treatments. The college is forward thinking on all strategic initiatives and leads the industry as an institute of higher learning.  They offer training and support staff and faculty in development. There is longevity with staff and faculty. Some staff and faculty been here over 20 years. This speaks for itself.
cons:
Negative prior employees post unfair reviews, probably from people that under performed, holding a grudge. 
Parking on campus  is limited.

job_title: Administrative in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Had a job
- Great teachers
- Nice location
- Free acupuncture
cons:
The administration does not take care of it's faculty or students.  The teachers are disgruntle because they have not received a raise in over seven years.  There are a large group of students who consistently do not receive their financial aide checks on time, they are due around weeks 3-4, but for some were not available until weeks 10-11, and the same students were affected every term. The staff ignored this and did nothing to correct it.  To make matters worse, they even threatened to drop these students from their classes because they were not able to pay for registration before the deadline. 

Additional Cons:
Low pay
Unprofessional management
Very corporate
Low morale and morals
Poor communication
No opportunity for growth

job_title: Instructor in Metuchen, NJ
pros: The school gave me freedom to enhance the curriculum and teaching methods as I saw fit. Department meetings offered a welcome environment for constructive reflection about the school, curriculum, and student issues. The faculty were friendly and for the most part open to discussing material.
cons: As a contract / adjunct instructor my income fluctuated from semester to semester. The school allowed in some students who were clearly unprepared for the rigor of the school either because of educational background, language, or in rare instances psychological health. Also because of the poor job outlook for acupuncturists, it was hard to encourage students to complete the program when they would be incurring so much debt.

job_title: in Chicago, IL
pros:
*The teachers truly give students a wonderful experience
*The students learn a lot and become very successful
*The majority of the departments are wonderful
cons:
*No room for new ideas
*DOA is incompetent at their job and blames others
*Need help with marketing, but have no desire to change whats wrong

job_title: Clinical Assistant in New York, NY
pros: During my time at PCOM I worked along side some wonderful people and dedicated students. Free acupuncture was the only real benefit.
cons: Very poor compensation for the amount of work involved in a high volume clinic requiring an intense amount of multi-tasking. High turn over and reluctance to hire on more workers to lighten work load and prevent understaffing.  A toxic environment with clear favoritism. No support from under-qualified upper management if one does not fall into favorite category.  Poor communication. Very disorganized. Poor benefits package. Non sensical policy enforcement.

review_title: Invest more in staff, students to shine
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The people are generally fantastic
cons: administration pinches pennies to the point that it's difficult to impossible to be effective in any role

job_title: Student Services in Chicago, IL
pros: The clinic treatments were great.
cons: I put in a considerable about of time to this company. Bottom line, you are just an employee to them. I saw many changes happen throughout my years there. None were for the better. It’s sad because the actual learning that takes place in classes is amazing. If you are looking for a place that insults, takes advantage, doesn’t recognize you as a human being and not part of a community, then this is for you.

job_title: Admissions in San Diego, CA
pros: I currently work for PCOM San Diego and I love it!  The faculty are passionate about what they do,  the staff are dedicated to the mission,  and we have the best students!!
cons: Some growing pains...nothing major.  The campus in San Diego is  great but we may grow out of it at some point.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: The students and teachers are very passionate and create a wonderful atmosphere to work with.
cons:
It is for-profit and became doubly-so while I was there. Turned admissions into the stereotypical "call center". Reps were ordered to spend 8 hours a day dialing from lists, many of which were years old. Eventually told to stop leaving messages, but just move on to the next number. We had promising prospective students who cut off all communication with us and the timing seemed to be right when we started calling them non-stop. If you want to work in admissions, this is not for you. However, if you feel your shoulders and neck are not suffering enough in your current job, you enjoy trying to convince people on welfare that they should take out loans to get a degree in a field they probably won't make enough to survive on (NYC has way too many practitioners already so unless they are young and business-minded it will be very tough), and if you want to further your grand career in telemarketing, this is the job for you.
Scheduling is alternating late and early days but if a student shows up late, expect to be there very late.
Oh, and they do not offer any vacation/sick hours until after you have been there 1 year. None at all - so don't assume you'll be able to use some after 3 or 6 months like normal places.

review_title: PCOM SD the good and bad
job_title: Management in San Diego, CA
pros: PCOM SD has hired some great staff recently. Good work life balance, free treatments, amazing faculty, abd overall a great vision/future outlook. The education students receive is far beyond any competitors.
cons: Increased pay/benefits for employee retention/morale needed

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: some of the staff and students make coming to work feel less stressful.
cons: Upper management and corporate don't care about anything except for how much money you can make for them, then you can't get any type of increase.

job_title: Admissions in San Diego, CA
pros: I work at the San Diego campus in the admissions office.  Great environment for my department. We work hard, care about the students and their success and have fun together.
cons: Pcom keeps bad employees and it affects everyone else

job_title: Herbal Clinic Manager in New York, NY
pros: Wonderful learning environment. Hands on herb experience.  Great for brushing up on your medical Mandarin.
cons: This was a work study position and should not have been. No training. No manual. Very little supervision.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Working with kind and giving people
cons: Nobody is well treated or well paid and too much politics going on an the mid to upper levels

job_title: Teacher's Assistant in Jamaica, NY
pros: Very friendly and helpful. Putting the customer first assisting with proper scheduling and rescheduling of patients appointments. Knowledgable and pleasant.
cons: Most of the staff were women and sometimes very moody.

job_title: Admissions Representative in San Diego, CA
pros:
Interesting subject matter.
Great teachers and students
cons:
Too many people in charge.
Too many office politics.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in San Diego, CA
pros: Central location, friendly campus, motivated students
cons: Became a medical school and lost the charm

job_title: in Brooklyn, NY
pros: people are nice, friendly and supportive.
cons: compensation is not good, no benefit.
